Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Reactive and Refractory Metal Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will deliver a system that can continuously process advanced refractory metal alloys from elemental, scrap or preprocessed feed stock into powder or small castings. The advanced hybrid plasma arc induction furnace uses the latest in clean melting techniques maintaining the full theoretical properties of these promising materials. This is a direct processing route for near net shape products. Advanced titanium alloys, for example, require special processes to maintain their material properties. This process will allow the development of specialist alloys without the cost and complexity of large and expensive foundry processes and rolling mills. The process developed takes pure elemental material and produces castings or powder in one direct cycle.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be the creation of new methods for development of specialist and advanced reactive and refractory alloys. Currently there is no economically viable route for these alloys to move from small, lab-scale experiments to use in large-scale commercial applications. This new process will speed the process of transitioning these materials into emerging applications. The overall objective of this project is to create a pilot-scale plant to produce castings and powder of these specialist materials. Some selected material systems where this new process will have a potential impact include advance titanium-based shape memory alloys and intermetallics such as niobium?]silicide based compounds. These new materials will create value for customers and users in the medical and aerospace industries, among others. The new process will be commercialized via the sale of a toll production service for castings and powder, and also via direct sales of the resulting equipment. Finally, the ability to easily produce pilot-scale quantities of novel alloys more cost-effectively will enhance the scientific understanding and application of these materials.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
SBIR/STTR Award Number: 1256255

Arcast Inc.

NSF SBIR Phase II: 
Reactive and Refractory Metal Processing


The SBIR project funded by the NSF has allowed Arcast Inc. to develop
a method for taking elemental refractory or reactive metal and melt, alloy and
atomize or cast it in one continuous process. The process is completely ceramic free, using the latest in cold crucible and non-contact melting techniques, and allows clean contamination free metal alloys to be produced such as advanced titanium alloys. The pure theoretical properties of these advanced materials can be maintained without the risk of ceramic inclusions. The continuous nature of the process from raw material to finished product (powder) consumes a fraction of the energy used in the collection of processes to achieve the same result in the current industry.  It also greatly reduces the cost to allow a greater and more cost effective range of powder metallurgy materials and products to be produced. The single process reduces lead times and contamination.


Now that the process has been proven and set up for production, Arcast is working with a range of customers and markets to produce these advanced materials. These materials will be used in the latest shape memory materials, thermo-electric materials, aerospace and medical markets, just to name a few. The powder will directly be used in additive layer and net shape manufacturing.


As Arcast engages in the larger scale production of these materials and powder, it will grow its customer base and partnerships to best meet the market demands. New companies and business are in formation and new
jobs have been created in support of this growth.

This NSF funded development has come at a perfect time to address
the growing demand for these advanced alloys and materials in powder and cast forms.


Last Modified: 05/31/2015
Modified by: S. Long
